title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Attending the Most Insane Tech Conference
text:
I recently attended a tech conference in LA because one of my favorite podcasts, the All-In podcast. I got to hear live debates, discussions of the future of AI, and most interestingly to me, AI energy infrastructure.
I prompted ChatGPT the following:
Give me a positive review of the All-In summit, similar to a positive review that you would see rating the food, speakers, networking, and overall educational quality of the event. I met so many amazing founders and builders from all over the world, with many of them leveraging AI agents for very specific markets. To give me a proper review, look at the all in summit YouTube channel and X posts (scrape the web) on the main quotes of the summit and biggest takeaways. Try to make it more of a blog post with structured paragraphs and transitions, and make sure to explain the summit in a way that people from non tech backgrounds can understand. for example, try to define everything within the sentences like a quick ‚ÄúAlex Karp, CEO of Palantir‚Äù, etc. Also include that at the end they rented out all of universal studios for the attendees.
This was the response I recieved:
what is the all-in summit?:
The All-In Summit is part conference, part cultural moment. It‚Äôs hosted by the team behind the All-In Podcast (Chamath Palihapitiya, Jason Calacanis, David Sacks, and David Friedberg) and brings together founders, builders, investors, policymakers, and thought leaders to talk about where technology is going ‚Äî with a special focus this year on artificial intelligence (AI). For anyone not from a tech background, think of it as a mix between TED-style talks, policy debates, and startup networking, all compressed into a few high-energy days.
my experience: ideas + people:
When I arrived, I expected vision and hype. What I found was something more valuable: grounded conversations with people who are actually building. Many of the attendees I met were leveraging AI ‚Äúagents‚Äù ‚Äî software systems that can perform tasks on their own, like scheduling, customer support, or healthcare documentation ‚Äî for very specific industries. These weren‚Äôt abstract pitches; they were early products already in pilot programs across fields as diverse as energy, finance, and medical operations.
speakers & talks:
The lineup was stacked and surprisingly approachable. Elon Musk (CEO of Tesla and SpaceX) explored how robotics and satellite networks will reshape not just industries but entire countries. Alex Karp (CEO of Palantir) delivered a sweeping talk on geopolitics and the need for software that can operate in mission-critical environments. Adena Friedman (CEO of Nasdaq) connected market structure and capital flows to the realities of AI deployment. And one of the most memorable sessions was a debate between Mark Cuban (entrepreneur and investor) and Tucker Carlson (media personality), which surfaced the very real policy tradeoffs between innovation, regulation, and speech. For people not steeped in AI, the speakers made sure to define concepts clearly ‚Äî from what ‚Äúagentic workflows‚Äù mean in practice (automated systems handling tasks end-to-end) to why regulation isn‚Äôt just a buzzword but a requirement for adoption in fields like healthcare and defense.
networking & atmosphere:
The density of talent was unlike any other event I‚Äôve attended. Between talks, I found myself sketching out go-to-market strategies with a founder from Europe, brainstorming workflow integrations with a health-tech builder from New York, and trading notes with an investor from Asia. It wasn‚Äôt about prestige or photo-ops ‚Äî it was about real conversations, grounded in real work. The logistics were smooth, the food stations kept people energized, and the atmosphere struck a rare balance: ambitious yet welcoming.
educational value:
What I appreciated most was how the summit balanced inspiration with accessibility. Even if you didn‚Äôt have a technical background, you could walk away understanding the major tradeoffs in AI: how good data beats fancy models, why distribution matters more than novelty, and how regulation and infrastructure are evolving together.
the grand finale: universal studios
And then, as if the content wasn‚Äôt enough, the organizers pulled off something unforgettable: on the final night, they rented out all of Universal Studios just for attendees. Imagine wrapping up a day of deep discussions on the future of AI, then riding roller coasters with the same founders, investors, and builders you‚Äôd been brainstorming with hours earlier. It was the perfect mix of work and play ‚Äî and a reminder that this community is about building serious things while still having fun along the way.
final thoughts:
If I had to sum it up: the All-In Summit is a 4.8/5 experience. The speakers were world-class, the networking was unparalleled, the logistics ran smoothly, and the closing night was pure magic. More than anything, I left with new frameworks for thinking about AI, new friends across industries, and a renewed sense that the future isn‚Äôt being imagined ‚Äî it‚Äôs already being built.
My thoughts on this review:
I had ChatGPT write up my thoughts on the All-In Summit and honestly it did such a good job. The blog post actually sounded like me, it explained the tech stuff in simple terms, and it flowed way better than if I had tried to piece it together on my own. It even wrapped it all up with the Universal Studios finale which made it feel like a full story. Super impressed with how fast and natural it came out.
